line.commentary: This opening line sets up a fascinating paradox - how can one know the world without leaving home? The grammar here is simple negation (不) + verb (出) + object (戶).
Note how [以] functions here - it indicates means/method. The structure is: [by-means-of] + verb + object. This creates a powerful connection between the first and second lines.
闚 is a very specific word for 'peek through a small opening' - the precision of Classical Chinese can be remarkable!
彌 is an intensifier meaning 'increasingly' or 'more and more' - watch how it creates a building sense in these parallel lines.
是以 ('therefore') often signals an important conclusion or lesson is coming. 聖人 (sage) is a key concept in Daoist philosophy - one who has achieved great wisdom.
The final three lines follow a powerful parallel structure. Each begins with 不 (not) followed by a verb, 而 (and/yet), and a result. Can you see how this builds to the chapter's conclusion?
